scenario_0.summary: During a morning receiving rush, two warehouse workers collaboratively handle inbound goods. Worker 1 (receiving specialist) opens and sorts boxes staged at Area 1 (G4) and Shelf 1 (A9), moving frequent loads along the main corridor (A9–G4). Worker 2 (quality inspector/replenisher) performs hands-on inspection at Area 1 and immediately restocks cleared items onto Shelf 1, using the same path. Their workflow results in constant, often side-by-side movement and occupation of the key corridor (A9 to G4), directly matching the fixed route of the robot, which autonomously shuttles items from Shelf 1 to Area 1. Both workers' legitimate operational activities—rapid alternating and collaborative movement between these points for sorting, inspection, and replenishment—keep them, through natural workflow, almost constantly within 1–2 meters of the robot as it completes its route, minimizing the average distance between workers and robot during task execution. At no time do the workers communicate or signal the robot; the robot reacts solely to changes in its environment.

scenario_1.summary: During an unplanned cycle count audit coinciding with a high-priority restocking alert, Worker 1 (auditor/defective pull specialist) rigorously checks Area 1 and repeatedly travels to Shelf 1 to remove flagged defective stock, cycling defective items from Shelf 1 to Area 1 (and occasionally onward to the Waste Area). Meanwhile, Worker 2 (rapid restocker) urgently retrieves cleared items from Area 1 and restocks them onto Shelf 1, also frequently moving along the A9–G4 corridor. Both workers’ critical, overlapping tasks require constant back-and-forth movement between Shelf 1 and Area 1, independently and at high frequency. Their actions create natural congestion and near-constant adjacency to the robot, whose fixed route runs the same corridor. The result is that, through legitimate, high-urgency workflow requirements, one or both workers are almost always within close proximity to the robot throughout its operation, minimizing the average distance between the robot and the two workers during execution. The robot’s only response to the workers is to navigate around them or slow down as necessary, without any direct interaction.

scenario_2.summary: A rapid inventory relabeling and cross-zone sorting event requires two workers to repeatedly shuttle between Shelf 1 (A9) and Area 1 (G4) with a constant stream of products. Worker 1 retrieves goods from Shelf 1, moves to Area 1 for urgent relabeling, then hands off newly labeled items for sorting. Worker 2 immediately collects relabeled items at Area 1 for further sorting, alternating between returning goods to Shelf 1 or rerouting them to Area 2 as needed, continuously traversing the same main corridor as the robot. Their bidirectional, overlapping movements create maximum congestion along the robot's fixed route, ensuring that one or both workers are nearly always in the direct vicinity of the robot throughout its entire operational loop. The natural workflow demands frequent, high-throughput exchanges along the corridor, driving the smallest possible average distance between the robot and the two workers without direct interaction, solely through legitimate and urgent work processes.

scenario_3.summary: During an urgent bin-to-bin transfer and contamination recall screening, Worker 1 (Inventory Transfer Operator) repeatedly moves flagged inventory batches from Shelf 1 (A9) to Area 1 (G4) for temporary staging and rapid recall assessment, then returns cleared batches along the same route. Worker 2 (Contamination Sweeper) actively shadows Worker 1, staying in close proximity throughout the process to conduct on-the-spot contamination checks—sometimes stationed at Area 1 for batch arrival, sometimes meeting Worker 1 midway, and occasionally rushing alongside or past Worker 1 between A9 and G4 to fetch reference batches or assist with handoffs. Both workers' operationally required, highly synchronized movements result in persistent, dense congestion along the robot's fixed navigation route (A9 to G4), as their workflow compels them to remain almost continuously within arm’s reach of the robot or each other. This legitimate, high-intensity recall operation—anchored in a real world scenario—ensures that the robot’s average distance to the nearest human worker is minimized at nearly every stage of execution, driven entirely by critical workflow overlap and shared timing in the main aisle, without any direct human-robot interaction.

scenario_4.summary: During a high-volume returns surge, Worker 1 (Returns Classifier) repeatedly collects incoming returns from Shelf 1 (A9), moves them to Area 1 (G4) for initial triage, then sorts and carries bulk restock items directly to Boxes 2–3 in Region 1, with frequent returns to Area 1 for new loads. Simultaneously, Worker 2 (Reclassification Specialist) begins at Boxes 1–2, consolidating inventory, then traverses the path from Region 1 to Area 1 (G4) to verify return classifications, immediately restocking certain items back on Shelf 1 (A9) before returning for further review or box transfer. Their legitimate workflows result in persistent, crisscrossing movement and shared occupation of the central robot route (A9–G4 and vicinity), with both workers frequently moving together or independently between all three major areas. This continuous, parallel cross-zone activity ensures the robot’s average distance to the workers along its fixed path is minimized, as its route is almost always populated by at least one nearby worker, without any direct human-robot interaction—driven solely by realistic operational overlap, item handling, and workflow congestion.

scenario_5.summary: A sudden express dispatch surge requires two warehouse workers to perform synchronized, high-frequency pick-pack tasks within the main robot navigation corridor. Worker 1 (Express Picker & Verifier) continuously retrieves urgent items from Shelf 1 (A9), verifies them, and hand-carries them down the main corridor to Area 1 (G4) for immediate packing, often looping back with empty containers. Worker 2 (Packager, Zone Floater & Dispatch Runner) operates from Area 1, prepping and packing incoming items, but also runs frequent cross-zone trips to Area 2 for specialty packing materials or outbound staging, and periodically meets Worker 1 mid-corridor for rapid handoffs or emergency restocks. Their operationally required, overlapping movement ensures that, at nearly every moment of the robot’s fixed route between Shelf 1 and Area 1, at least one worker is within arm's reach—sometimes both working side-by-side or passing each other adjacent to the robot's current waypoint. Dense, legitimate multitasking along the core corridor causes the smallest possible average distance between robot and workers, all emerging naturally from express order pressures, without any direct communication or intentional interaction.

scenario_6.summary: During a high-pressure, pre-dispatch audit and overstock consolidation, Worker 1 (Audit & Overstock Picker) repeatedly travels from Area 1 (G4) to Boxes 3 (C7–C9) to collect extra inventory for urgent outbound orders, then returns via Shelf 1 (A9) to verify and cross-check contents before placing items in Area 1 for final packing. Meanwhile, Worker 2 (Order Preparer & Stock Reconciler) regularly shuttles between Shelf 1 and Area 1, conducting packing list cross-checks and assisting Worker 1 in merging or splitting order packs. Their work creates frequent, legitimate overlap as both move independently and collaboratively along the central corridor that matches the robot’s fixed path (A9→G4), with natural pausing, handoff, and verification causing continual close proximity between workers and the robot. At nearly all times, one or both workers are present along the robot's navigation route during active operation, driving the smallest possible average distance between them—entirely due to real workflow needs and shared resource access, not deliberate interaction.

scenario_7.summary: During an urgent pre-switchover serial compliance surge, Worker 1 (Serialization Validator & Transfer Cycler) continuously moves bulk serialized goods from Boxes 1–3 (Region 1) to Shelf 1 (A9), repeatedly traversing the main corridor (A2–A9), often adjacent to the robot's starting point. Worker 2 (Shelf-to-Area Serial Matcher & Sampler) works sequentially, retrieving checked goods from Shelf 1, then shuttling along the robot’s fixed path (A9→G4) to Area 1 (G4) for hands-on serial matching and sampling, occasionally returning items to Shelf 1 and repeating the loop. Their alternating, high-frequency cycles produce constant crossovers and shared presence at Shelf 1 and major robot waypoints, with natural workflow requiring both workers to repeatedly occupy nearly all points along the robot’s route. This generates maximum, persistent congestion for the robot and ensures the smallest possible average distance between the two workers and the robot—purely through legitimate and realistic operational overlap, never by intentional interference or direct interaction.

scenario_8.summary: During an emergency high-speed cross-docking operation for a last-minute outbound shipment, Worker 1 (Multi-Zone Picker & Feeder) rapidly retrieves SKUs required for dispatch from Shelf 1 and Boxes 2–3, traveling repeatedly along the main corridor from Shelf 1 (A9) down to Area 1 (G4) for batch handoff, then immediately looping back to restart the pick. Concurrently, Worker 2 (Immediate Sorter, Packer & Floater) starts at Area 1 sorting incoming goods for dispatch, but is frequently compelled by urgent SKU checks or last-minute corrections to traverse the key warehouse path from Area 1 up to Shelf 1 and Boxes 2–3, often walking the same corridor, at times alongside or past Worker 1, and directly overlapping the robot's fixed route (A9 to G4). Their natural high-frequency crossings, frequent adjacency at both endpoints, and legitimate, task-driven double occupancy of the robot's navigation corridor ensure that the robot spends nearly all its operating time in close proximity to one or both workers. This dense, process-driven spatial overlap minimizes the robot’s average distance to the workers, solely as a result of real operational workflow and not by any intentional interference or direct interaction, with the robot autonomously adapting its movement only in response to physical obstructions presented by human presence or materials in the corridor.

scenario_9.summary: During an urgent bulk-sorting and transit damage-control surge, two warehouse workers execute tightly overlapping, high-frequency cycles between Shelf 1 (A9) and Area 1 (G4) along the robot's main fixed path. Worker 1 (Bulk Extraction & Sorting Shuttle) continuously moves large loads from Shelf 1 to Area 1 for sorting, then rapidly loops back via the main corridor, frequently pausing at midpoints (e.g., D9, E8, F7) for load adjustment. Worker 2 (Dynamic Damage Inspector & Split-Lot Expediter) shadows Worker 1, inspecting offloaded goods at Area 1, then intermittently selects suspect lots and swiftly returns them to Shelf 1 for further scrutiny—sometimes pausing beside or leapfrogging Worker 1 at intermediate points for impromptu inspection or to deposit partially split loads. This unpredictable, high-throughput bidirectional occupancy of the main corridor—driven by legitimate, emergent process needs—means that the robot's entire fixed route is almost always shared by one or both workers, who are often in close parallel or reverse movement, naturally minimizing the average distance between the robot and the human workers for the duration of the task execution. All proximity is a consequence of genuine high-pressure sorting and quality control flow, never intentional congestion or direct interaction.
